chapter.name: MaxScore Editor: The User Interface
chapter.p: The MaxScore Editor is a GUI designed for editing MaxScore scores directly in a Max patcher window. The backbone of the Editor is the MaxScore mxj object which implements the Java Music Specification Language in Max.
In this tutorial, we will get familiar with the GUI of the MaxScore Editor and introduce its basic functions.

Access Maxscore.Editor by right-clicking on an empty space of a Max patch window, then selecting “Paste From>MaxScore>Editors>maxscore.editor.clipping.maxpat”. You are now ready to start working on a new project.
Lock the patcher and open the Editor window by clicking on the “Open Editor” button inside the bpatcher.

ul.li: Welcome to the Max Editor window! On the upper left-hand side you will see the Menu Bar where you can access various functions.

Look at the Sidebar on the right. There are four tabs, Tools, Pitch Utility, Scorpions and Picster. In this tutorial we will look at functions in the first two. We will go over the others in the next tutorials.
Now click on File>New Score from the top Menu Bar.
In the main canvas, you will see the Score View, where you will create and edit your scores. You can always return to this page by pressing Shift-1.
Press Shift-2 to go to the Staff View. Here you can customize your staves with various attributes.
Press Shift-3 for the Preferences, where you can change various other score attributes.

chapter.ul:
Now let's create our first score!
By default, the tempo is set to 60 BPM, the time signature to 4/4 and the clef to a treble G-clef. To change this, use to the ‘Tools’ pane of the sidebar and make your choices accordingly.
To change the time signature, click on the ‘Meter’ button right below the clef box and enter number of beats and subdivision such as separated by a space ‘7 8’. Click the ‘Tempo’ button next to it to set the tempo.
Let's add the first note. In order to add notes, double click or ctrl-click on a blank space on the designated measure. The note is blue now which means it is selected. If you want to transpose notes, you can either cmd-drag (Mac) or ctrl-drag (Windows), or use the keyboard shortcuts u, j, i, k, o, l for respective transpositions. You can always access the list of shortcuts from the menu: "Edit>Shortcuts".
To convert a note into a rest, click the rest button on top of the third column in the Tools panel, or alternatively use the keyboard shortcut r.
To add dynamics or articulation, select a note and then choose from the Tools bar the corresponding symbols. e.g. for dynamics check the 5th column.
If you wish to add a crescendo or decrescendo to your score, drag-enclose the notes to which you want this to apply and click the respective symbols from the Tools pane.
If you want to turn your notes into tuplets, select the notes and then choose the corresponding symbols from the Tools pane (5th and 6th columns, ‘3’, ‘5’, ‘7’, ‘9’, etc.)
To add repeats or barlines, select the measure and then click on the corresponding symbols at the bottom of the Tools pane.
chapter.p: For larger scores, navigate through the score by using “Navigation” tool at the bottom of the window. Type the number of the page you wish to display or use the arrows to move to other measures (single arrows) or pages (double arrows).
Zoom in or out the score by changing the corresponding value for the “Zoom”.
